narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer:
The project is expected to generate de-identified demographic, clinical, and MRI imaging data (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS) from 110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls. In addition, data needed to create a global unique identifier for the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) will be collected. The estimated amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project includes:*
 Tabular demographic/clinical data: approximately 220 records
 MRI imaging data (structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS): approximately 220 datasets, each containing multiple files
 *Derived measures and documentation (data dictionaries, protocols, README): variable amount

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All scientific data collected in this project will be preserved and shared with the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). This decision is based on NIH's genomic data sharing guidelines and the importance of making research findings publicly available. The preservation and sharing of these data will facilitate further research, improve transparency, and promote reproducibility.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:*
 *Study protocols
 *Data collection instruments
 *Derived measures (e.g., summary statistics)
 *README files describing data format, quality control procedures, and any limitations

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer: Specialized tools, software, and/or code are not required to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. However, familiarity with MRI analysis software (e.g., FSL) may be beneficial for some users.

The project will apply common data standards to enable interoperability of datasets and resources.*
MRI imaging data will be stored in BIDS format, which is a widely accepted standard for organizing neuroimaging data.
*MRI imaging data will also be organized according to the Dublin Core metadata standard.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The primary repository for archiving scientific data and metadata will be the Open Science Framework (OSF), which has been approved by the NIMH as meeting NIH policy for data sharing and management.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers, such as DOIs assigned to datasets in the OSF repository.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: Data will be made available to other users no later than the end of the performance period (approximately 2 years). Data will remain publicly accessible indefinitely, unless specific restrictions or limitations are imposed by informed consent agreements.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: The sharing of these data is subject to the requirements of the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), which includes protections for participant privacy and confidentiality. The project will adhere to NIH's genomic data sharing guidelines and any applicable institutional policies.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the shared scientific data will not be controlled, as it will be publicly available through the OSF repository.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: Human research participants' privacy, rights, and confidentiality will be protected through de-identification (e.g., removal of names, dates) and storage in a secure database. These protections are consistent with the requirements of the NIMH Data Archive (NDA).

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Plan will be monitored and managed by the lead PI, who will oversee data management activities, including data quality control, metadata documentation, and data sharing procedures. The frequency of oversight will be regular, with progress reports submitted to the NIMH at the end of each performance period.
